ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Senegal went through an economic crisis in the 1980s, and cut off from government support, many women emerged from their domestic roles to become breadwinners for their families. They formed collectives, called Roscas, which act like credit unions with an emotional component. Participants contribute a predetermined sum which gets redistributed to members who need short term loans to run their business.The women are able to raise their families' standard of living by raising and selling food crops, or making handicrafts. They meet regularly, share problems and help one another out. It is a cooperative very much in keeping with the African sense of community. The Rosca movement may be a key out of poverty.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="521" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">For College; Adult audiences.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="530" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Previously released as DVD.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="546" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">This edition in French and English with English New York, NY : Filmakers Library, 2001. 1 streaming video file (24 min.). 002400 two-dimensional moving image tdi rdacontent computer c rdamedia online resource cr rdacarrier Global business and economics in video Title from resource description page (viewed May 24, 2011). Senegal went through an economic crisis in the 1980s, and cut off from government support, many women emerged from their domestic roles to become breadwinners for their families. They formed collectives, called Roscas, which act like credit unions with an emotional component. Participants contribute a predetermined sum which gets redistributed to members who need short term loans to run their business.The women are able to raise their families' standard of living by raising and selling food crops, or making handicrafts. They meet regularly, share problems and help one another out. It is a cooperative very much in keeping with the African sense of community. The Rosca movement may be a key out of poverty. For College; Adult audiences. Previously released as DVD. This edition in French and English with English subtitles. Credit unions Senegal Dakar. Women in cooperative societies Senegal Dakar. notes_summary_ssim: Senegal went through an economic crisis in the 1980s, and cut off from government support, many women emerged from their domestic roles to become breadwinners for their families. They formed collectives, called Roscas, which act like credit unions with an emotional component. Participants contribute a predetermined sum which gets redistributed to members who need short term loans to run their business.The women are able to raise their families' standard of living by raising and selling food crops, or making handicrafts. They meet regularly, share problems and help one another out. It is a cooperative very much in keeping with the African sense of community. The Rosca movement may be a key out of poverty.
